posts.name: Arjan
posts.cooked: Our team has had problem with our climb design and weight, so we are searching for fast lightweight climb solutions if anyone has some goated climb teams with light weight solutions they want to point out.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: In general it seems that the lightest mechanisms “ride piggyback” on an existing mechanism (eg an elevator or arm).

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
A lot of teams with lightweight climbs will be talking advantage of existing robot architecture. So I am not sure if you just want to be looking for "lightweight ".

(For instance we have a larger arm that the climber is attached to that is responsible for the majority of the lift)

This is all ignoring potential center of mass sensitivity and a host of other dynamics

posts.name: Brandon King
posts.cooked:
You may also find that this piggyback method is much easier if you go for a shallow cage rather than a deep cage, certainly if your robot wasn’t designed with the deep cage climbing integrated from the beginning.

You can do a much more conventional climb style with shallow cage.

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked: The problem I’ve seen with adding shallow cage climbs is that most elevators are already taller than the bottom of the shallow cage, so two sideways hooks are needed rather than one hook that point up. This type of climb tends to be harder to line up.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Shallow climbs seem to be -really- rare this year.  I’ve been collecting them on this thread.  If you don’t have a mechanism that is capable of high forces then your minimum weight will be driven by the motor+gearbox+ drum system, followed by the weight of the “grab the cage” mechanism.  A spear can be pretty light, especially one designed to work with the 3" hole in the bottom of the cage.  You will likely also need some guides to get the cage into the right position for latching it; these can be pretty light.

Shallow climb: anyone building it? General Forum

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Because of their rarity, shallow climbs are (IMO) not worth doing [other than for the skills your students would learn doing it]. Almost always your money/time/effort would be better spent someplace else on your robot.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
john3928:

In general it seems that the lightest mechanisms “ride piggyback” on an existing mechanism (eg an elevator or arm).

Facts.

link_counts.title: Team 7724 Robot Reveal 2025 (smallest comp bot this season?!)

posts.cooked: If you were to add a hook to your elevator as was recommended in this thread, how would you stay up after the game is over without a ratcheting mechanisms (because that would stop you from using elevator for scoring during the game)

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: If you are already using pneumatics, WCP makes a solenoid-powered friction brake that you can trigger when needed.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: You could also add a servo-pushed stop pin on an elevator to lock it.
